title: "Violence is a Key Aspect to Warwick's Theme, and We Want to See How Far We Can Push That"
body:
Yes, Riot. That's exactly right. Rengar has already delivered on all the aspects you could want out of a feral hunter type champion. He feels like a skilled, predatory beast and his leap and roar are very animalistic. If you don't find something to really differentiate Warwick from Rengar, this rework is going to fall flat both gameplay-wise and thematically.

So yes, thinking about Warwick, I definitely want to see more of a violent character. The Hyena skin really encompasses what I like most about Warwick. His auto attacks are wild and all over the place, and his running on all fours is perfect to the idea of a werewolf lost in the hunt.

Violence is key, but you should also emphasize that Warwick **has no control.**

Perhaps this wasn't part of Warwick's original design, but Rengar didn't exist when Warwick came out. Rengar is cold, calculated, and vicious. He has the strength of an animal but the intelligence of a man. Warwick needs to differentiate that by being unable to cling to what's left of his humanity. Playing Wawrick should feel wild and dangerous. The player him/herself should be afraid of the monster they are controlling. 

The game is 13+, I think, so you should be able to show some blood, right? Even though you cleaned it off a lot of splash arts, I think this is the champion that needs it the most. You have Darius bleeding his enemies out after all. Warwick needs something similar. Maybe when he has three stacks on an enemy that enemy becomes bloody and scarred for the duration of the passive.

I remember the last time Warwick was up for a rework you were planning to keep the AP ratio on his Q because there was concern that making him AD focused would create similar drain-tank problems to Aatrox. That's understandable, but maybe a better solution is to simply restrict his healing to jungle monsters altogether? You could make Warwick have a higher damage potential if he simply didn't have the extra longevity in his kit against champions, which would make him a much better ganker since he wouldn't be so reliant on his teammates for damage.

And then we get to his W. The skill that is lauded by pro players as providing the most free gold worth of stats to a team in the game. This skill definitely should be scrapped entirely and replaced with something more interesting and impactful. In the previous Warwick rework, we saw that it was a point blank AOE fear similar to Volibear's Majestic Roar except that it could affect champions.

I think this idea could work. To make it better differentiated from Volibear and Rengar, you would need an ear-piercing, haunting howl to accompany it, rather than a roar or a scream. Something that shows a man pining for his true form, something wistful and lonely but also bloodthirsty.

Warwick's proposed rework E was a dash from one location to another and then back again that could go over walls. It was tuned so that when he was at the other point, for a split second, he could W and Smite, so that he could basically contest objectives over walls. This was made significantly easier by his E passive also being changed to show monsters below 50% health as well, so even red and blue buffs could be contested by the Feral Hunter. 

This change would make Warwick into an insane control jungler that takes more skill than Nunu or Skarner. I approve of it whole-heartedly. 

And finally, his ultimate. This is the skill that really has the most potential for violence. I urge Riot to cast aside the instinct that this is a kid's game and really embrace what video games have become from a graphics perspective. Every claw slash, every rip and tear, should have a serious pain-inducing sound effect, and his claws should swing in broad, unpredictable arcs that show him not slashing, but pulling the skin off his target. Like a beast desperate to get at the enemy's heart.

If you read the State of Gameplay Update post where the title quote comes from, the Rioter says "We like Warwick as a champion that essentially teaches new players how to jungle".

They plan to keep him simple, and likely he will be stuck in one role. That's fine. 

I mean, you can't exactly argue that Riot hasn't shoe-horned champions into one role with some of their recent reworks. Skarner's passive **only** works when he's jungling.

>If you read the State of Gameplay Update post where the title quote comes from, the Rioter says "We like Warwick as a champion that essentially teaches new players how to jungle".

I get that you need easy and simple champs for this exact purpose (though Riot has been phasing out "easy" champs for the past couple years at least with these reworks), but if you try to make a person learn how to jungle on a healing-intensive champ, they are absolutely fucked on any other champ they play. I learned on nocturne, and when I made the switch to udyr (who was pretty god tier at the time) I couldn't gank for shit. That's because noc has absolutely free ganks with his ult and a targeted fear (this was back when fear caused random movement, so it was a hell of a lot better). The same thing will happen if you make some learn the jungle on warwick. They will get used to how easy it is to heal up and have absolutely no concept of how to conserve hp in the jungle, kite the camps, etc. Keep warwick "simple" but don't let him be boring (and yes, he's fkin boring as hell right now).

Kalista -> forced into adc by riot design
Kindred -> forced into jungle by riot design
Morde rework -> forced into adc by riot design (the double exp part, now almost entirely removed)
Fiora -> forced into top lane due the fact that most of her damage is in her passive (old Fiora could still jungle quite well)
Skarner rework -> forced into jungle due to "shrines"

Riot been forcing champions in roles for quite a while now.

Ya? And that's fine. If riot wants to design a champ for a specific role that's totally fine, that's not what I was saying at all. My issue is that if they design a champion designed to be very low skill and very noob friendly with a low skill ceiling, you will end up with a VERY boring champ that no one outside of bronze will really play. That is terrible for game health, and the reason why riot has been systematically been phasing these kinds of champs out with the latest rounds of reworks.

Warwick isn't there to teach that. He's there for new junglers to learn how to manage objectives, when/why to gank, how to apply pressure to lanes, etc. The built in healing on his passive means that new junglers don't ALSO have to learn about HP management, camp kiting, etc at the same time as everything else. He's a stepping stone; yeah, WW currently practically jungles for you, but his only initiation is by ult or Flash, almost his entire damage output is countered by Blind and reduced by armor, and his attacks are loudly telegraphed, with no CC to lock targets down outside of his ult.

He has a very low skill floor, but also a low ceiling. Which is how he should stay.

but keep it for hyena doe.

> "Violence is a Key Aspect to Warwick's Theme, and We Want to See How Far We Can Push That"

Considering werewolves started as a way to explain serial-killers and murderers, I approve of this.

Cursed beasts are most interesting when they're, well, cursed. The danger of tipping into a violent, uncontrollable rage is one of the most interesting parts of werewolf stories, and adding that flavor to Warwick's aesthetic could make him a very captivating champion.

This might get lost in the comments, but I really want to see {{champion:19}}'s Blood Scent remade into a detection ability. I imagine activating it will cause him to smell for a 'scent trail' (like an orange-red version of {{champion:27}}'s Poison Trail) that gives him bonus MS and / or AS while 'on' it. Maybe they can combine his Blood Scent and Howl into the same ability, letting him reactivate it to howl, slowing nearby enemies, but slowing his prey if he's on their trail regardless of distance.

Why a detection effect? Because Warwick is a hunter and it would behoove him to have such an effect. It would enhance is theme and flavor, allow for some neat gameplay, give him a powerful tool to control of the jungle, while also being decent utility in general and a counter to stealth! Crucially, because it's detection it would not grant sight of his target (thus no targetibility), only information as to their recent position. Where there enemies nearby? Someone hiding in that bush? Someone trying to juke through brush? Smell their fear! 

I've always thought it strange that Shaco can go invis to deny Warwick his Blood Scent reveal. That said, if it wasn't a reveal, but instead a detection effect, it would probably be good for the vision game as a whole. Riot, please.
